Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Cybersecurity Solution for Collecting, Storing, and Using Substation Relay Settings Data
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is to provide a new capability to the U.S. electric utility industry that (1) enhances system reliability and (2) enables linking cyber and physical system analyses in new ways. The power grid's reliable, resilient, and secure operation is a vital national interest - underpinning economic vitality, high living standards, and health/welfare. The power grid, one of the most complex systems ever built, is vulnerable to extreme weather, natural disasters, criminal acts, and hostile attacks. It has some 3,100 providers generating, transmitting, and/or distributing power, who operate more 70,000 high-voltage sub-stations. Each substation has tens of relays that open and close breakers - controlling power flows. System planning staffs require accurate, up-to-date relay settings to populate computer simulations that shape reliable system design and operation. Typically, system protection staffs maintain relay settings databases specific to their needs. System planning staffs often find these databases are ill-suited for their needs - extracting/adapting the needed data subsets for planning simulations is a manual, man-hour intense effort. The system operator is also obligated to protect relay settings data during collection, storage, and use to prevent exploitation by criminals or other hostile actors.

This I-Corps project seeks to provide power system operators a new capability to streamline/harmonize their efforts to collect, store, use, and secure relay data for system studies/analysis. This new capability will also enable power providers to link their physical system simulation results and cyber network maps - opening the door to security effort prioritization with new, previously unachievable, synergy. The research objectives are two-fold. First, the project seeks to provide an integrated, end-to-end capability enabling automated relay settings data collection, central storage, and automated, tailored data provision to system analysts. The physical product will be a standalone, purpose-built computer system that incorporates multiple essential functions: database, FTP server, webserver, parser, and application-specific software. Second, it is envisioned to expand the capabilities to leverage recently introduced Software Guard Extension (SGX)-enabled CPUs, which provide encrypted memory space for securely processing sensitive data. The purpose-built computer linking SGX-enabled CPUs will provide a new level of security on networked computer systems simulating power system behaviors.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Background

The U.S. power industry has some 3,100 providers generating, transmitting, and/or distributing power.  The power grid, one of the most complex system of machines ever built, is vulnerable to extreme weather, natural disasters, criminal acts, and hostile attacks. 

The North American Electric Reliability Corp. (NERC) currently enforces (with financial penalties) more than 80 standards promoting system reliability.  NERC's 2017 Long-Term Strategy anticipates significant power system changes impacting reliability:  (1) power system resource mix, (2) fast-acting digital protection and control technologies proliferation, and (3) increased integration of distributed energy resources.  Therefore, NERC anticipates expanded data collection, validation, modeling, and analysis requirements to assess reliability impacts -- driving changes in NERC Standards.

To sustain reliable operations and meet evolving regulatory requirements, power providers will be driven to increasingly detailed, accurate, up-to-date component information -- including the vast network of sub-station relays that control power flows.  Power providers will need this information to design (and upgrade) their systems, plan for contingencies, and deliver power.  Power providers are also obligated to protect power system information and controls against hostile actors intent upon disrupting their systems.

Intellectual Merit

Our project's broad objective was to investigate power provider interest in an integrated capability enabling (1) the automated collection of substation relay settings data, (2) the data's secure transmission to central locations, (3) long-term data storage and retrieval, and (4) the automated provision of appropriately formatted data to power system planners supporting simulation and analysis requirements.  We envision a purpose-built computer (using off-the shelf components) upon which our purpose-written software will perform/enable the enumerated functions.

Broader Impacts

The U.S. electric power grid's reliable, resilient operation is a vital national interest -- underpinning economic vitality, high living standards, and health/welfare.  There are over 3,000 power providers in the U.S. -- operating over 70,000 high-voltage substations -- each with tens of relays controlling circuit breakers.  Our product opens the door to increased productivity -- and significant cost avoidance. 

We believe that our envisioned product's commercialization is well-timed to meet current and emerging NERC standards pushing the electric power industry to secure sensitive data and fulfill expanded system study requirements.  We anticipate that our product will increase productivity by reducing the man-years otherwise required to obtain and maintain up-to-date, accurate data.  We believe a significant fraction of the 3,100 power providers will need the capabilities that we envision.

Kaedago Team Activities:

  • Attended the on-site opening and closing National I-Corps training sessions in Denver, CO.
  • Traveled extensively to meet face-to-face with electric power industry users, influencers, and decision makers.
  • Completed 125 customer discovery interviews during the 6-week program; 115 of these were in-person.
  • Reported significant interview results, insights gained, "Value Proposition" / "Business Model Canvas" revisions during five intervening weekly WebEx video teleconference meetings.
  • Attended 3 major meeting events (Columbia Grid User's Meeting, North American Electric Power Reliability (NERC) Systems Analysis & Modeling Sub-committee Meeting, and the DEFCON Cyber Security Conference).

Outcomes

  • We believe that our product concept matches a compelling industry need -- and anticipate submitting an SBIR application. 
  • We identified additional development work necessary to provide a minimally viable product for first adopters.
  • We narrowed our initial target market to ~ 600 larger-scale power providers that have both (1) compelling operational requirements and (2) available resources to fund purchase, installation, and follow-on support.  Our target audience for "selling" our solution will be transmission engineers and their superiors.
  • We broadened -- and sharpened -- our understanding of the multiple dimensions to be thoughtfully addressed in crafting a sound "Business Model Canvas".
